top_categories.workout_context: Hart Hills' Michigan rolling gravel rewards steady threshold power. Surging and recovering costs more watts than just holding.
Hart Hills' Michigan rolling, Local event forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 55 miles.
At Hart Hills, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Hart Hills. Train it until it feels boring.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Hart Hills' demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before May.
Varied gradients on Michigan rolling gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
When someone attacks on Michigan rolling gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Hart Hills, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
55 miles on Michigan rolling gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Torque for headwinds and Michigan rolling gravel. When cadence drops below 70rpm, muscular strength keeps the watts up.
2-minute all-out efforts on Michigan rolling gravel. Closing gaps, responding to attacks, sprinting for position. Train the burn.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Hart Hills’s 55 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Hart Hills requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on michigan rolling gravel to build confidence. Expect: michigan rolling, local event, midwest gravel.
